title: Fireworks

But Nazuna, unhappy over her mother's decision to remarry and leave their countryside town, plans to run away and has secretly chosen Norimichi to accompany her. When things don't go as planned, Norimichi discovers that a glowing multi-color ball found in the sea has the power to reset the clock and give them a second chance to be together. But each reset adds new complications and takes them farther and farther away from the real world - until they risk losing sight of reality altogether. [GKIDS]… Expand
critic_reviews: Fireworks takes you on that little journey. It may affect you deeply, or it may just come and go, a fizzling sentimental aside in an otherwise hectic day. But it’s hard to deny that it approaches its fantastical story with maturity and grace, and a thoughtfulness about what it would truly mean to leap into a “what if” and seriously consider never coming out again.
It’s confusing and disorientating but brings back dreamy teen angst like the strongest of madeleines.
There are more engaging fireworks, or at least small sparks, when the film begins to dig into the feelings, friendships and jealousies of its two main protagonists.
Despite its novel plot, and some lovely music and incidental artwork—the title fireworks, the rugged seaside and that glittery magic ball are all beautifully rendered—the film quickly drags.

Where Your Name’s star-crossed protagonists were fully formed characters who held equal weight in the narrative, Fireworks is very much told from the male point of view, and Nazuna seldom rises above “free-spirited object of desire.”
The unrealized potential makes the rote line style and stagnant backdrops seem all the blander.

For all its temporal twists and lyrical, sometimes remarkably photorealistic backdrops, Shinbo’s movie has none of “Your Name’s” narrative intricacy or stunning visual richness, much less its radical cross-gender empathy. These Fireworks look depressingly flat from any angle.
A strange little movie that attempts the tricky feat of combining comedy, drama, sci-fi and romance, but it doesn’t get those individual elements right so it never coheres as a whole.
Akiyuki Shinbo and Nobuyuki Takeuchi's time-travel device mostly just exists to complicate what is, at heart, a trite and sexist love story.
What should be tender and whimsical feels repetitive and off-putting.

reviews.content: Fireworks is an unfortunate let down of a movie. I'm surprised this anime even got a US release. It's just so strange, and the characters are completely forgettable. It's just so strange, and the characters are completely forgettable. It's a half-hearted attempt at a love story with some time travel BS that never goes anywhere. It's also an argument about the nature of fireworks that never goes anywhere. The one saving grace of this movie is that the animation is pretty to look at.
An interesting story that feels unable to start up and fails to be enjoyable. Although the animation work is very good that does not exempt it at all of its poor narrative.
